Dear Mr. Hannah:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)204-6992.

IV. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
Section (3) The ratio formula for direct care workers shall correspond
Description with the institution’s purpose and the needs of the
residents and shall assure the continual safety, protection,
and direct care and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The ratio of staff is not meeting the needs of the youth at facility as
there are multiple youth with suicidal, homicidal, and self-harming
thoughts. Youth was being transported by one staff and sitting in
the front seat of a vehicle where they were able to put the vehicle
into gear and grab the keys. Youth was chased through a cornfield
and brought to the hospital for injuries sustained.
Investigation The complainant in this investigation was anonymous and was not
able to be contacted for any additional information.
Youth A and Youth B were interviewed in person during an
unannounced face-to-face visit on 11/23/2022. A full interview is
3

not conducted at the time in order to coordinate with DHHS
Worker 1. This writer made contact with the Administrator to
gather documents and staff and youth to be interviewed.
Incident 1
Youth A was interviewed on 11/28/2022 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated
that she recalled the incident in question where she was being
transported by a staff member and was able to grab the keys and
run away. She stated that Staff 1 was the staff member with her,
and that there were no other staff involved. Youth A recalled that
they were being transported to a court meeting and on the way
back they stopped at a gas station approximately a few miles from
the facility. Youth A stated that she grabbed the keys from the van
while Staff 1 was in the driver seat, and immediately jumped out of
the car and ran away. Eventually Youth A made it a few blocks
down the road and jumped off a very short bridge to the ground
below and hurt her ankle. By that time Youth A recalled there were
additional staff who had arrives to help her. Youth A stated that
she eventually voluntarily got in a car to go back to the facility and
was seen by the nurse for her ankle. Youth A stated that all of this
was caused by Staff 1 asking her if she was doing OK after the
court meeting and Youth A being triggered. Youth A stated that
she did not believe Staff 1 was being negligent in any form. She
also stated that she has been transported by one staff many times
in the past without issue and was not aware of any facility rules
against this.
Staff 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 12/05/2022
during an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. She
confirmed that she was the staff member who had given Youth A
a ride to her court meeting as alleged. Staff 1 stated that she
requested that Youth A sit in the front seat out of concern for
safety. Staff 1 stated a similar course of events as Youth A that
resulted in Youth A taking the car keys and running away to
eventually be found and taken back to the facility. Staff 1 stated
that she has driven other youth alone in the past, and that there
are no policies at the facility that prohibit this. She also stated that
there are times in her work with Youth A that Youth A had safe
behaviors and a baseline that would allow for this type of
transportation.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 12/21/2022. While Supervisor 1 was no longer employed by
the facility at the time of this interview, she did say that she felt
4

that there were many times when staff were stretched too thin and
struggled to maintain supervision and safety of the youth placed at
the facility. When asked to clarify, Supervisor 1 stated that what
she really meant was that ratios were always met and supervision
requirements such as one-on-one plans, but it generally meant
that staff were mandated to continue shifts or were working
overtime or were coming from other locations on the campus in
order to help out with staffing. Supervisor 1 stated that she was
the supervisor at the time of the incident in question involving
Youth A and Staff 1. She stated that she would have preferred two
staff be involved in the transportation, but that was not a
documented requirement.
Incident 2
Youth B was interviewed on 11/28/2022 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. He
confirmed that she had an incident where she had to go to the
hospital after escalating and self-harming as was described in the
allegations. She stated that she ran out of the facility and into a
field during this incident and recalled that staff were following her.
Youth B stated that she couldn’t remember exactly what staff this
was. Youth B also described several other recent incidents that
involved self-harm, fights with other youth, restraints, or
hospitalization trips. She stated that there were not any times that
she could recall during any of these incidents where there was not
sufficient staff in the facility with her or outside of the facility.
Staff 2 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 12/21/2022
during an announced face-to-face visit at the facility. She
confirmed that she was a part of the incident in question where
Youth B ran from the facility and received minor injuries as a
result. Staff 2 also confirmed that she was a part of a separate
incident involving Youth B where she attempted to tie a sweatshirt
around her neck to self-harm. Staff 2 stated that incident ended
with Youth B sitting on the floor and giving up the sweatshirt and
Staff 2 was able to de-escalate and talk with her. Staff 2 stated
other staff were involved in the incident. A review of the incident
report indicates that there is not concern that a lack of staff
available to meet ratios lead to Youth B’s self-harming attempt.
Incident 3
During separate interviews in this investigation allegations were
brought up that there was an incident involving Youth D self-
harming during his previous time placed at the facility. This
5

occurred on 11/17/2022 overnight. Youth D was able to take a
scrap piece of a T-shirt and wrap it around his neck to only have
staff remove it quickly. Staff 3 was a direct care worker involved in
this incident. She was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on
1/20/2023 over the phone. Staff 3 stated that Youth D had a safety
plan set up the night of the incident where he had two staff
involved in having eyes on supervision over the course of the
night. Staff 3 stated that there were more than two staff involved
with Youth D that night because he was escalated for a long
period of time. She recalled that he had his safety blanket over
him as he was laying in bed, talking with staff when they noticed
that he stopped talking for a few seconds, and appeared to be
struggling to breathe. Staff 3 stated that she got her fingers
underneath the fabric on his neck and removed it from his hands
within seconds. Staff 3 then re-confirmed that there never was a
lack of supervision as required during the incident. She stated
that she later became aware that Youth D allegedly got his hands
on the scrap of fabric during his shower time earlier in the night
before her shift.
Staff 4 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
01/20/2023. She confirmed that she was a staff member involved
in the incident where Youth D self-harmed overnight during two to
one supervision. She gave a very similar course of events and her
recollection of what had occurred. Staff 4 stated that she pulled
the blanket off of Youth D when Staff 3 quickly figured out that the
youth may have been harming himself. Staff 4 stated that Youth D
had something tied around his neck and it was removed almost
immediately. Staff 4 stated that she did not know how Youth D
was able to procure this item to attempt at self-harm but was
confident that he did not do so under her watch while she was
supervising him. She stated that she had heard from Youth D that
he had gotten the scrap of fabric during a shower earlier in the day
and stuck it under his undergarments to hide it. Staff 4 stated that
she has acted as a one-on-one supervisor for several other youth
in her time working at the facility and has never had any concerns
about being out of ratio or not able to provide that enhanced
supervision.
Administrator was interviewed in person during an announced
visit to the facility with DHHS Worker 1 on 01/25/2023. He stated
that he had been involved in the incident of self-harm overnight
with Youth D because he had asked staff to contact him if any
such incident were to occur around that time. Administrator stated
that Youth D had admitted to unraveling the hem of a T-shirt
during shower time the evening prior to the incident because he
6

was able to do so while in a shower stall changing for a shower.
Administrator provided a consistent version of events that
occurred when staff stopped Youth D from self-harming in the very
early morning hours the next day.
Staff 5 was interviewed in person during an announced face-to-
face visit at the facility on 02/01/2023. She stated that she
remembered the Youth D incident and worked with him that day.
Staff 5 stated that there was not a concern over lack of
supervision of Youth D the evening prior or during the actual
incident of self-harm.
Staff 6 was interviewed on 02/01/2023 With DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit at the facility. She stated
that couldn’t remember is she was involved with Youth D, taking a
shower the night prior to his attempted self-harm, despite being
named by other staff as working with Youth D that day. Staff 6 did
describe the shower requirements that she makes sure staff
enforce when there is a one-to-one or two-to-one supervision
situation.
Staff 7 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
02/07/2023. She confirmed that she was involved with Youth D
during one-on-one as well as two-to-one supervision
requirements. Staff 7 stated that Youth D’s enhanced supervision
has always been able to be accomplished when she has been
involved and she believed that even with this involvement it is
possible for someone like Youth D to procure a small item and
hide it on their person during showering time because there are no
rules in place from the past facility to witness youth nude before,
during, or after their showers.
Incident 4
Youth C was interviewed on 01/18/2023 during an announced
face-to-face visit at the facility. Allegations from other youth were
shared with her in regard to instances where she did not have
one-on-one supervision as she needed. Youth C stated that she
does not believe she has ever lacked one-on-one supervision
when it was required. She did state that there may have been a
time where she shared one-on-one supervision with another
youth, meaning that both of the youth required this, and one staff
filled the role. When asked for any more details Youth C stated
she could not remember when this may have been or what staff
member may have been involved. Youth C was also interviewed
on 02/10/2023 to ask for any more details in regard to allegations
7

made by other youth that she has lacked one-on-one supervision.
Youth C described a situation where she had attempted to self-
harm with a fork as well as a situation where she ran out of her
unit at night. Youth C stated that both instances involved staff
members covering the one-on-one supervision and she noted that
she was not able to hurt herself in either situation because they
intervened.
Incident 5
During the course of the investigation new allegations were
brought up that Youth A was able to procure a razor blade
sometime during the month of December 2022 and use it to self-
harm during a time that she had one-on-one supervision. The day
that this allegedly occurred was 12/22/2022. Both Staff 11 and
Youth A were interviewed separately and presented consistent
accounts of how Youth A was able to have a razor in her
possession on that date through Christmas gift bags received by
the facility for the youth. Both individuals stated that Staff 11 was
able to take the razor away from Youth A without incident before
any self-harm occurred.
Documents reviewed:
• Staff schedules for the facility for the months of August
through December 2022. Scheduling indicated a proper
coverage of ratio needed to supervise the youth placed at
the facility.
• Safety Plan dated 11/16/2022 - Written by the facility
Therapist and states that “Staff will stay within 6 feet of
Youth A during waking hours and post by her bed during
sleep hours.” Safety plan is signed by the Therapist and
Youth A on 11/16/2022 and staff began to sign off receipt of
the plan from 11/21/2022 to 11/28/2022.
• Incident Report dated 11/18/2022 - Provided consistent
account of Youth A attempting self-harm with a slap band
bracelet during the early morning hours of 11/18/2022.
• Incident Report dated 11/18/2022 - Provided consistent
account of Youth B attempting self-harm during the evening
of 11/16/2022.
• 1 on 1 Staffing Request & Approval Form for Youth C dated
02/05/2023 and signed by the facility Therapist. This
document indicates one-on-one supervision of Youth C
began on 12/20/2022 but was not yet approved by Youth
C’s case management. It also notes that the enhanced
supervision covers 16 hours per day and does not include
nighttime hours.
8

• Safety Plan updated 12/08/2022 – Written by the facility
Therapist and states that “Staff will stay within 6 feet of
Youth A during waking hours and post by her bed during
sleep hours.”
• Documentation from Caro Community Hospital for a visit
made for Youth A on 12/22/2022. This visit was made to
receive medical attention for gastrointestinal discomfort on
Youth A’s part. No self-harm injuries are noted that could
have resulted from having a razor.
• Log sheet for the unit where Youth A resided on
12/22/2022. This confirms that one-on-one staffing was
sufficient for the youth on this date.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews with staff and youth as well as
documentation review there was no evidence to support a finding
that staff ratios were insufficient to meet the needs of the youth
placed at the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents’ needs, implementation of treatment plans,
and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff member was texting while driving.
Investigation Staff 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 12/05/2022
during an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. She was
interviewed regarding the incident of Youth A’s AWOL off campus
under her supervision. During this interview Staff 1 noted that she
was texting another staff member while driving Youth A just prior
to the AWOL attempt. Staff 1 stated that she did this because she
sensed escalating behavior from Youth A and she wanted to alert
others and get assistance without Youth A noticing, but also knew
that it was risky to text while transporting a youth.
Documents reviewed:
• “Procedure for Transporting Youth” policy from the agency
that states “Do not use handheld cell phone while operating
vehicle”
• “Employee Handbook” policy from the agency that states
"Employees may not use a hand-held cell phone while
operating a vehicle – whether the vehicle is in motion or
9

stopped at a traffic light. This includes, but is not limited to,
answering or making phone calls, engaging in phone
conversations, and reading or responding to e-mails,
instant messages, and text messages."
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews with staff as well as
documentation review there is evidence to support that Staff 1
drove in an unsafe manner while transporting a youth. Per the
agency's Employee Handbook texting and driving a youth is not
allowed.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
Description direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time between the
variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff were sleeping during overnight third shift duties.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 11/28/2022 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. While
describing circumstances surrounding staff supervision and any
self-harm or AWOL attempts, Youth A stated that she has seen
Staff 8 sleeping on several occasions while working as the third
shift staff responsible for the youth overnight. Youth A noted that
Staff 8 would often fall asleep while being the only staff working
during that shift. She also stated that she self-harmed one night
when this occurred.
Staff 8 was interviewed on 12/05/2022 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 8
recalled the incident that Youth A described where she had self-
harmed over the course of the night. Staff 8 initially denied falling
asleep, but then stated that there have been times working third
shift where she would put her head down or close her eyes. Staff
8 stated that she couldn’t say that she has never fallen asleep
during that overnight shift.
Staff 9 was interviewed 12/05/2022 with DHHS Worker 1 during
an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated that she
commonly works third shift. When asked if she has ever fallen
10

asleep during that overnight shift Staff 9 stated that she believes
that she has before. Staff 9 stated that she has seen other staff
asleep during that overnight shift as well, and stated Staff 8 as the
only name she could think of specifically.
Staff 10 was interviewed on 12/21/2022 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated
that she generally works third shifts with the youth and is
sometimes alone, and sometimes with another staff for whatever
extra supervision might be needed. Staff 10 was asked about
staff sleeping during third shift and she recalled a specific incident
where a youth was able to self-harm while she suspected that
Staff 8 had fallen asleep as the assigned overnight staff that
evening. Staff 10 stated that she had reported to the unit and she
had seen Youth A awake and while talking to her noticed fresh
wounds on Youth A’s arms from self-harm. Staff 10 stated that
she immediately sought out medical attention for Youth A. She
recalled Staff 8 sitting at a table near the front door of the unit and
Staff 8 looked very groggy and had no idea that Youth A had been
awake or self-harming for any amount of time.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews with staff and youth there was
evidence to support a finding that staff have fallen asleep while
performing third shift duties caring for the youth placed at the
facility.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & Public Act 116 722.120 (c) Investigation, inspection, and
Section examination of conditions, books, records, and reports;
Description access by department, bureau of fire services, or local
authorities; records; report; forms; confidentiality; disclosure
of information; availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department; failure of
licensee to cooperate with investigation, inspection, or
examination.
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the
department, and encouraging witnesses, such as staff and
household members, to provide accurate and truthful
information to the department.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff member falsified documentation of overnight supervision.
Investigation Staff 8 was interviewed on 12/05/2022 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. While
discussing the allegations that she had fallen asleep while
performing third shift duties, Staff 8 noted that she was aware of
the requirements that she “check on” the youth in the unit every
11

hour at the least. The third shift log for that evening is marked off
in a fashion that suggests youth were viewed eyes on every 15
minutes.
Documents reviewed:
• Unit Shift Log Entry dated 11/17/2022 for the evening of
11/17-11/18/2022 - This third shift log shows 15 minute
checks on youth and is not consistent with Staff 8’s account
of how frequently youth were checked during her interview
on 12/05/2022.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews with staff as well as
documentation review there was evidence to support a finding that
staff falsified records while performing third shift duties caring for
the youth placed at the facility, and therefore violated Public Act
116 722.120 (c).
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Staff are to perform varying interval checks not to exceed 15
minutes when youth are asleep or otherwise outside the direct
supervision of staff. The agency should ensure these are
occurring in varying intervals and not on every 15 minutes.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
Description resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Safety plans were not followed allowing a youth to self-harm.
Investigation Staff 10 was interviewed on 12/21/2022 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit to the facility. In regard to
the incident where she discovered that Youth A had self-harmed
while Staff 8 was the third shift staff, Staff 10 stated that she was
not sure if Youth A was on a safety plan or not. She stated that
there had not been any enhanced supervision or other
interventions applied to Youth A’s care that night as would be
common with a safety plan.
Staff 8 was interviewed over the phone on 01/25/2023 with DHHS
Worker 1. She confirmed that she was the third shift staff member
working the night of Youth A’s self-harm noted in the added
allegations. She stated that she had not been made aware of an
updated safety plan signed the day prior designed to help Youth A
avoid self-harm. Staff 8 stated that she did not see a safety plan
for Youth A in the days after that, either, and that the instruction
was always to sign them after reading them to document the
12

information was provided to all who need it. Staff 8 also confirmed
that she had spent the evening of 11/17-11/18/2022 sitting at the
table near the front door of the unit and was not physically near
Youth A’s bed.
The Therapist who authored Youth A’s safety plan from
11/16/2022 was interviewed on 02/10/2022 during an
unannounced face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated that it
has always been her practice to immediately place a new safety
plan for a youth in the hands of the staff currently working with that
youth and/or to put a copy of that new plan in the binder in the
unit, requiring that staff sign off on it as they begin new shifts.
Therapist has stated that she printed the safety plan and put it on
the binder on the unit as well as handed it to working staff during
the evening of 11/16/2022.
Documents reviewed:
• Safety Plan – Staff for Youth A signed by Therapist on
11/16/2022. Various staff signatures confirming receipt of
the information start at 11/21/2022.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews with staff as well as
documentation review there was evidence to support a finding that
staff did not adequately provide for the specific needs of the youth
placed. As of 11/16/2022 Youth A had a safety plan authored that
stated that staff be within six feet within waking hours and post by
her bed during sleep hours. The staff that would have been
responsible for this on the evening of 11/17-11/18/2022 stated that
they were not aware of this plan and Youth A was able to self-
harm.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
